Figure 3 shows signals of scattered parameter \(S21)  i.e. out

Put transmission or surface wave magnitude obtained throughout the journey, starting from baseline \(edge of the sensor), point a \(0 mm - outside copper) until point A \(20 mm - outside copper) for an in
It was observed that the magnitude of the resonance peak increased gradually from starting point to mid-point \(M), then gradually dropped as the robotic-arm moved further from point M.
See figure in Figures section.
\[Click to Enlarge]
The signal is always a qualitative information useful for non-ACM engineering groups such as optics, physics, biology, etc.
However, for ACM engineering groups, a more mathematical/ statistical quantitative method such as a Root Mean Square Deviation \(RMSD) is additionally adopted for the obtained signals \[10, 15].
Figure 4 shows the formula and the application procedure.
The RMSD is represented as a percentage frequency function, which can
Increase or decrease or can be unstable with unpredictable fluctuations.
This RMSD is considered as a sensitivity
Measure of smart materials used for engineering monitoring \[6, 11].
5. See figure in Figures section.
\[Click to Enlarge]
Figure 5 shows the sensitivity \(RMSD) of surface wave out
Put as the robotic arm moved over the top of the curve-linear shell \(and LSP sensor).
The shape of the graph is similar to the shape of the shell, which was slightly steep on one side.
6. See figure in Figures section. \[Click to Enlarge]
Figure 6 shows the sensitivity of the surface wave out
Put above the waveguide, as the robotic arm moved over the top of linear waveguide.
The
Increase of separation between the concrete blocks increased the RMSD.
The signals are not shown here, but are available in the associated journal \[10].
However, the RMSD graph shows more meaningful interpretation/ proportionality compared to raw signals.
